thread.title: Eels star avoids conviction over assault
thread.title_full: Eels star avoids conviction over assault

title: Eels star avoids conviction over assault
text:
Parramatta Eels star Kenny Edwards has avoided a conviction after he pleaded guilty to common assault against his former partner by pouring a drink over her as she lay in bed. Parramatta Eels NRL player Kenny Edwards in court last year over the charges. Source: News Corp Australia 
Magistrate Theo Tsavdaridis dismissed the domestic violence charge on condition that the Eels star enter into a six-month good behaviour bond saying the 27-year-old needed, “management and oversight rather than a conviction and punishment.” 
The court heard that following a fight on the morning of December 11 last year, Edwards sprayed water in the face of his then partner Madison Campbell, 26, before pouring the contents of a beverage on her while she was in bed. 
Mr Tsavdaridis said although the assault did not involve physical violence it was “demeaning” and domestic violence matters should never be trivialised. 
“Domestic violence is a problem of considerable proportions in the community,” he said. 
The court heard New Zealand-born Edwards had been the victim of domestic violence himself at the hands of his father while growing up. 
“He himself saw his mother commit suicide following a lengthy period of dysfunctional familial upbringing,” Mr Tsavdaridis said. thKenny Edwards pleaded guilty to common assault having poured a drink over his partner. Source: News Corp Australia 
In references provided to Mr Tsavdaridis it stated that football had provided Edwards with the “discipline and structure” that he did not have as a child. 
A second charge of intimidating Ms Campbell was withdrawn. 
The court heard Edwards and Campbell are no longer together and she lives interstate. 
Outside court Edwards said it was “negative” for him to be at court. 
“I just want to apologise to my young family, to my club and to the NRL but I’m a positive person and I can only move forward from here,” he said. 
“I just want to move on with my life and I look forward to this year.” 
Edwards’ rugby career has been mired by bad behaviour. 
He was dumped by Manly at the start of 2009 for disciplinary reasons and was picked up by St George Illawarra Dragons. 
He played for the Dragons for two years before he was again axed for disciplinary reasons in 2011. 
Edwards joined the Eels in 2013 on a one-year contract which was extended for a further two seasons. 
He had knee-surgery in 2016 and became embroiled in an out-of-competition drug scandal when he swapped his drug test sample with teammate Kaysa Pritchard which saw him banned for nine months.
